content: How can I help you today?
I guess I’m here because my wife wanted me to come. Things have been tough at home, especially with our son. I’m not even sure what to say or how this works.

Thank you for sharing that and for being open about how you're feeling. It sounds like things have been challenging at home, and it means a lot that you're here even if you're unsure where to begin. Maybe we could start by talking a bit more about what’s been going on with your son or how things have been tough. Whatever feels right for you.

My son’s been acting out a lot—tantrums, not listening, getting in trouble at school. My wife and I can’t seem to agree on how to handle it, and it’s putting a strain on everything. It’s like no matter what we do, nothing helps, and I’m starting to feel like I’m failing as a parent.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming, like you’re trying your best but still feeling stuck and unsure of the right path forward. It’s clear how much you care about your son and your family, and it’s tough when the things you try don’t seem to make a difference. How have you been coping with all of this?

Honestly, I’m not coping well. I’ve been feeling really drained, and I can’t focus at work or enjoy anything outside of all this stress. It feels like everything’s falling apart, and I just don’t know where to even start fixing it.

That sounds really heavy, carrying all of that stress and feeling like it’s affecting every part of your life. It shows how much you care that you’re thinking about how to make things better, even when it feels so overwhelming. When everything feels like it’s falling apart, it can be hard to know where to begin. What do you think has been the hardest part of all of this for you?

The hardest part is feeling like I’m failing everyone—my son, my wife, even my daughter. I know they’re all struggling in different ways, and I don’t feel like I’m there for any of them the way I should be. It’s tough knowing things are slipping, but I just feel stuck.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot on your shoulders, wanting so much to be there for your family but feeling stuck and unsure how to move forward. That pressure of wanting to do right by everyone you care about must be incredibly difficult. What do you think would help you feel a little less stuck right now?

Maybe if I could figure out a way to help my son, things would feel a little less overwhelming. It feels like everything is connected—his behavior, the stress in my marriage, feeling like I’m not supporting my daughter. But honestly, I don’t even know where I’d start when it comes to helping him.

It sounds like helping your son feels like the key to easing some of the pressure everywhere else, but not knowing where to start has been weighing heavily on you. That’s understandable, especially since it’s all interconnected and feels so overwhelming. What steps have you already tried with your son, and are there any approaches that you’ve thought might help but haven’t explored yet?

We’ve tried setting stricter routines, talking to him calmly, giving consequences, even some rewards for good behavior, but none of it seems to stick. My wife and I have talked about maybe seeing a specialist for him, but I’m not sure if that would help or if it’s worth it. It just feels like we’re grasping at straws at this point.

It sounds like you and your wife have put a lot of effort into trying different approaches, and the fact that you’re considering seeking outside help shows just how much you want to support your son. It must be frustrating and disheartening when things haven’t worked out the way you hoped, especially when you’re trying so hard. What do you think about the idea of seeing a specialist—are there any parts of it that make you feel unsure?

I guess part of me feels like going to a specialist just means I’ve really failed, like I should’ve been able to handle this as his dad. And what if it doesn’t help at all? It’s just hard to know if it’s the right decision.

It makes sense that you’re feeling conflicted. On one hand, there’s the hope that a specialist might help, but on the other, it feels personal—like it might mean you’ve fallen short as a dad. That’s a tough place to be, especially when you care so deeply about being there for your son. At the same time, it takes courage to even consider options like this, and it shows just how committed you are to finding the best way to support him. What would it take for you to feel more confident in a decision like this?

Maybe if I knew that seeing a specialist could actually make a difference, I’d feel more confident about it. I just don’t want to get my hopes up too much or waste time and energy on something that might not help. It’s hard to know who or what to trust right now.

It’s completely understandable to feel hesitant about putting time and energy into something when the outcome feels uncertain. You want what’s best for your son and your family, but you’re also trying to protect yourself from more disappointment. Trust can be tough to build when things have been so challenging. What would feeling more hopeful or reassured about this process look like for you?

I think it would help if I could hear from someone who's been through something similar or if I knew more about what seeing a specialist would actually involve and how it could help my son. Right now, it just feels like this big unknown, and that’s hard to wrap my head around.

That makes a lot of sense—having more clarity and hearing from others who’ve been through something similar could feel a lot more grounding and help you move forward with less uncertainty. The unknown can be intimidating, and it’s natural to want to know what you’re stepping into. Would learning more about what specialists typically do, or maybe connecting with other parents who’ve taken this step, feel like a helpful next step for you?

I think that could help. It might make it feel less like a leap into the dark and more like something I can approach in a way that makes sense. If I can understand what to expect or what other parents have experienced, I might feel a little less lost about it all.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach—taking steps to understand and learn from others could make this feel more manageable and less overwhelming. It also shows how much you’re trying to get this right for your son and your family. Is there anything specific you’d like to explore or learn more about first, so you can take this process one step at a time?
